abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Health Sector
            Development Project for Tanzania were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the Sector Wide Approach (SWAp) has
            contributed to the alignment of both Development Program
            (DP) and Government budgeting and accounting through a
            single system thereby contributing to a reduction in
            transaction costs. Central, programmatic and SWAp funding
            are essential for implementation of health services in
            raising health indicators as exemplified by funding for NMCP
            Nutrition and HIV/AIDS program. At the time of project
            implementation, the SWAp contributed to greater sector
            coherence and consistency, which secured higher levels of
            both domestic and external financial resources for health
            throughout the implementation period. Compared to the set of
            loosely or non-coordinated projects and programs previously
            in place, SWAp delivered real improvement in sector
            coordination and dialogue. Non-salary, discretionary
            resources at local/facility level seem to have played a
            critical role in the results attained. It is an important
            lesson as we continue to consider supporting such resource allocations.
